Award.AbstractNarration: This project will support the activities of the CEDAR Science Steering Committee (CSSC) over the period 2012-2014. The CEDAR program supports research into the Earth's upper atmosphere with an emphasis on how material, momentum, and energy are transported through different atmospheric strata and across latitudinal and local time boundaries. CEDAR research also has important Space Weather and global change overtones. The CEDAR community meets annually, and the attendance at the CEDAR Workshop is of the order of 300. The participation of undergraduate and graduate students as well as of young professionals at the workshop is strong, and the CEDAR program has helped to launch the career of numerous individuals into the fields of aeronomy and space physics. The CEDAR Workshop in particular and the direction of the CEDAR community in general are planned by the CEDAR Science Steering Committee, working in conjunction with Program Directors from the NSF. Specific actions of this committee include the organization of the Workshop and an associated luncheon meeting, participation in another meeting in the Fall at the NSF in Arlington, and the publication of a newsletter, the CEDAR Post, which appears approximately semi-annually.

Performance_Institution.Name: Earth and Atmospheric Sciences, Cornell Univ.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CEDAR is an NSF program element which focuses research on the boundaries between different atmospheric regions and the processes that couple the regions together. "Regions" is a broad concept which includes strata at different altitudes, volumes at different latitudes, and also more abstract kinds of boundaries, for example charged vs. neutral constituents. Research at the interfaces is important for understanding how the upper atmosphere responds to and recovers from transient forcing to to space weather (from above) and terrestrial weather (from below). It is difficult since it often necessitates contributions from multiple disciplines.

CEDAR focuses attention on the boundary regions, develops infrastructure (including instrumentation, models, and codes) for performing the research, and ensures the vitality of the community involved in the research, mainly through student education, training, and professional guidance. The CEDAR Science Steering Committee leads the community, plans its annual summer workshop, and guides its evolution. This NSF award supported the committee in that role.

The main accomplishments of the CSSC during the award period were:

1. The introduction for a competitive process for changing the venue of the summer workshop. Universities and other institutions now compete to hold the workship which will move across the country, helping to promote CEDAR and the institutions that take part.

2. The creation of "grand challenge" workshops which help to focus CEDAR activities on the most important research topics and themes.

3. The redefinition of CEDAR as a kind of technology development wing of the larger aeronomy program at NSF.
